message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest Hirschsprung disease, which is characterized by an absence of ganglion cells in the distal colorectum resulting in functional obstruction. This can lead to bowel distention and the presence of a mass in the rectum. The absence of distal gas on the abdominal radiograph is also consistent with this diagnosis. Malnutrition, myelomeningocele, and cystic fibrosis are not typically associated with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest Hirschsprung disease, which is a congenital condition that causes obstruction in the bowel leading to accumulation of stool and gas in the intestine. The failure to pass meconium for 2 days after birth is also a key indicator of Hirschsprung’s disease. Malnutrition, myelomeningocele, and cystic fibrosis do not cause the same symptoms or physical examination findings as Hirschsprung disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the physical examination findings suggest Hirschsprung disease, which is characterized by failure to pass meconium, abdominal distension, and a mass protruding from the rectum. The absence of distal gas on the abdominal radiograph is also consistent with Hirschsprung disease. Malnutrition, myelomeningocele, and cystic fibrosis do not typically present with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest Hirschsprung disease, a congenital disorder in which certain nerve cells are absent in portions of the bowel, resulting in obstruction and constipation. The failure to pass meconium for 2 days after birth is also a common sign of the disease. Malnutrition, myelomeningocele, and cystic fibrosis may cause gastrointestinal symptoms, but are not consistent with the physical examination findings of a rectal mass and extrusion of rectal mucosa.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs suggest Hirschsprung disease, which is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the colon leading to functional obstruction, causing the rectal mucosa to extrude through the external anal sphincter. The past history of failure to pass meconium is also suggestive of this diagnosis. Malnutrition, myelomeningocele, and cystic fibrosis do not typically present with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of a mass protruding from the rectum, vomiting, and history of failure to pass meconium for 2 days after birth suggests Hirschsprung disease, which is a congenital disorder characterized by a lack of ganglia in the distal colon resulting in impaired relaxation of the rectum and obstructive symptoms. The explosive expulsion of gas and stool during digital rectal examination is a classic finding in Hirschsprung disease. Malnutrition, myelomeningocele, and cystic fibrosis do not present with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical picture suggests Hirschsprung disease, which is characterized by the failure to pass meconium and the presence of a rectal mass. The greenish emesis may also be an indication of intestinal obstruction. The explosive expulsion of gas and stool on digital rectal examination also supports this diagnosis. Malnutrition, myelomeningocele, and cystic fibrosis are not consistent with the clinical presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including failure to pass meconium and protruding mass, suggest Hirschsprung disease, a condition where there is a lack of nerve cells in the bowel walls, leading to difficulty passing stool. The greenish vomiting and distended abdomen are also consistent with this diagnosis. Malnutrition, myelomeningocele, and cystic fibrosis do not typically present with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with Hirschsprung disease, which is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal bowel, leading to obstruction and accumulation of stool. Failure to pass meconium in the first 48 hours after birth is a common presenting symptom of Hirschsprung disease. The distended abdomen, vomiting, and rectal prolapse are all characteristic findings. Malnutrition, myelomeningocele, and cystic fibrosis are not typically associated with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of bowel obstruction, including vomiting, abdominal distention, and absence of distal gas on radiograph. The protruding mass suggests rectal prolapse, which is often seen in patients with Hirschsprung disease. This disease occurs due to congenital absence of ganglion cells, leading to a lack of peristalsis in the affected segment of the colon.
